awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Carl Lian is " Moduli of Curves and Linear Systems." The host institution for the fellowship is Humbolt University , and the sponsoring scientist is Garvril Farkas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Enumerative geometry is the study of questions of the form: how many geometric objects satisfy a desired list of properties? Such questions are among the oldest in mathematics: for example, the ancient Greeks knew that exactly one line passes through two points in the plane, and Kontsevich generalized this in the 1990s to rational curves of higher degree through more points. In modern times, questions in enumerative geometry are encoded in the geometry of moduli spaces, which are geometric spaces whose points parametrize other geometric spaces. In this language, one can expand the scope of "enumeration" further, asking perhaps for the dimension of an infinite but continuously varying family of geometric objects (such as curves in an ambient space), or finer invariants such as its class in a suitable cohomology theory.

This project was principally concerned with such questions, with the central geometric objects being algebraic curves and related objects. Specific examples of geometric objects which have been successfully enumerated, suitably interpreted, include curves in certain natural ambient spaces of interest (such as projective spaces and more general toric varieties, hypersurfaces, and Grassmannians), branched covers of curves, 1-dimensional subgroups of abelian varieties, and linear spaces in flag varieties. Naturally, the questions and answers at hand take place in the world of moduli spaces of such objects.

New ideas, new questions and new connections to other disciplines have emerged in these investigations. 


Last Modified: 01/13/2025
Modified by: Carl Lian
